item.title: Fortnite Chapter 6 Season 3 Will Be Star Wars-Themed According To Leaker
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/fortnite-chapter-6-season-3-will-be-star-wars-themed-according-to-leaker/1100-6530405/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Fortnite Chapter 6 Season 3 is expected to arrive in May and a prominent leaker has revealed that it will be a mini-season focused on Star Wars, which has had multiple events and skins in the battle royale in the past.

According to Loolo on X, Season 3 will be a mini-season, running only 30 days, and will be themed around Star Wars. This means bosses, NPCs, points of interest, and items will be added to the game from Star Wars and the battle pass will be Star Wars-themed. Loolo said that the battle pass will feature four to five skins, although it's unclear if all of them will be Star Wars skins or if only some of them.

With the help of @X0X_LEAK, I can confirm that season 3 is Star Wars themed, with it lasting aprox. 30 days!

This lines up with how Fortnite and Star Wars have crossed over in the past, starting around May 4, sometimes used as a day to celebrate Star Wars--May the Fourth be with you. This is the same time of year Fortnite has had Star Wars events in the past. Fortnite also has tons of Star Wars cosmetics already, including Anakin, Luke, Leia, Darth Vader, Storm Troopers, and more, making it difficult to predict which characters might be getting skins in the upcoming season, especially with the possibility that there could be different outfits for characters that have already appeared.

Disney and Fortnite have collaborated for themed seasons in the past, including multiple Marvel seasons. Disney also invested $1.5 billion into Epic Games in 2024, with plans to build a persistent Disney universe with the Fortnite developer. Season 3 of Fortnite OG just kicked off as well, bringing back the old map and adding a battle pass featuring remixed versions of old skins.

item.title: Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet Reveals So Far Are Just The "Tip Of The Iceberg," Director Says
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/intergalactic-the-heretic-prophet-reveals-so-far-are-just-the-tip-of-the-iceberg-director-says/1100-6530396/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet is a new IP from Uncharted and The Last of Us developer Naughty Dog, and while it won't release until 2027 at the soonest, the game is in a playable state already and feeling "really good," according to director Neil Druckmann.

He told IGN, "We are playing it at the office and it's incredible. It's really good."

He added: "I'm so excited to finally put gameplay out into the world and show people about it, because we just showed you the very, very, very tip on the iceberg. The game goes pretty deep beyond that."

Druckmann is referring to the game's announcement trailer at The Game Awards in December 2024. The trailer (above) shows off some of the game's characters and cuts off just as things get brewing with an intense fight.

Intergalactic is a game "about faith and religion" that takes place around 2,000 years in the future in a universe that diverged from our own in the 1980s.

Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet is in development for PS5 but does not have a release window at this time. Druckmann previously admitted that Naughty Dog "still have a ways to go" in developing the game and he doesn't have a clear idea of the final form Intergalactic will take just yet.

The game features a number of celebrities in starring roles, including Tati Gabrielle as the main character Jordan, along with Kumail Nanjiani, Ashley Scott, and Tony Dalton.

Naughty Dog has at least one other single-player game in development right now, and while some expected it to be The Last of Us 3, that may not be the case.

item.title: Drug-Selling Game Explodes On Steam Charts, Surpassing Assassin's Creed Shadows
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/drug-selling-game-explodes-on-steam-charts-surpassing-assassins-creed-shadows/1100-6530401/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The DEA has Schedule 1 drugs, substances, or chemicals defined as "drugs with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse." It shares the name with a new game that's blowing up the charts on Steam and players can dive into early access now.

In Schedule 1, you take the role of a small-time drug dealer rolling into a new city with no cash, no product, and no hookups or clients. The game's objective is to build your drug empire from the ground up as you contend against law enforcement and rival deadly cartel members so you can expand your empire and become a drug kingpin.

Released just yesterday, Schedule 1 quickly climbed to the top of the charts of not only Trending Games, but also Popular Releases, and Hot Releases on SteamDB. The game even reached 116,408 concurrent first-day players--almost double that of Assassin's Creed: Shadows. It reached a new high today with over 131,000.

Some players might remember playing Drug Wars on their TI-86 in high school, and at its foundation, Schedule 1 seems similar in that aspect. However, Schedule 1 also has multiplayer capabilities that help you take your empire to greater heights. The game even breaks down your drug-making process to include monitoring lighting, growth, and even when to harvest your plants for the best product possible.

Schedule 1 is currently on sale and players who buy now will have early access until March 31, when the price will go back up by 25-50% afterwards.

item.title: Another Activision Division Has Voted To Unionize
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/another-activision-division-has-voted-to-unionize/1100-6530394/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Communications Workers of America announced on March 25 that user-research workers at Activision have voted to form a union that Microsoft is already willing to recognize.

Officially called Activision User Research Union-CWA, this is the first video-game-researcher union of its kind in the North American video game industry. A press release about the union's formation explains that it wants to fight for better wages and job security for those working in user research at the Call of Duty maker.

The massive number of layoffs the video game industry has seen over the past couple of years was also cited as a reason for the union's formation. Organizing Committee member Pat Dimaandal argues that "workers should not feel punished for pursuing a career that they love, and thatâ€™s why weâ€™re organizing toward long-term, sustainable careers in this industry."

The CWA confirms that there are now over 2,000 unionized workers at Microsoft-owned studios after the formation of this union. Unionization efforts began at Activision several years ago in the wake of the Civil Rights lawsuit against Activision Blizzard. Raven Software was the first studio to unionize, and Microsoft had to agree to allow unionization efforts at its studios during the process of acquiring Activision Blizzard. That opened the door to unions like this one and others at Microsoft-owned companies like ZeniMax Online.

CWA recently announced the United Videogame Workers-CWA union at GDC 2025 for those not working at a company like Microsoft. UVW-CWA is an industry-wide union that any game developer can join, and the CWA has confirmed it has already gotten over 350 members since it was announced last week.
